awd_titl_txt: U.S. China Planning Visit: Roots of Technological Innovation and Change in Ceramic Traditions of Sichuan Province
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will catalyze a long-term collaboration between U.S. and Chinese scientists to investigate mechanisms of technological innovation and change. Focusing on ceramic traditions of Sichuan Province, the specific research objective is to identify the circumstances that encourage and allow for the high level of experimentation that fosters technological change. Sichuan, in southwestern China, is an ideal location for studying long-term change, offering archaeological collections, historical archives, and modern potters who still work in a traditional manner, often in relatively isolated environments. Five main parameters that will be investigated are materials availability, production organization, geographic location, market types, and political stability. Research methods will involve a combination of field observations and interviews, mapping, historical and archival research, and laboratory analysis of representative ethnographic and archaeological ceramics. 

Developing a more sophisticated understanding of mechanisms underlying technological change is a central research issue in the social sciences, yet theory to explain the origins of technological innovation is sparse. This project aims to help fill that gap. Results from this work will contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of how and why technological change occurs in a variety of cultural contexts, especially ones that require adapting to challenging environmental and cultural issues. By understanding the factors that contribute to the flourishing of innovation, or to its suppression, it is more likely that our society can develop a supportive structure for technological experimentation, responsiveness to changing natural or cultural environments, and the ability to innovate when necessary for economic health.

por.por_cntn:
This project catalyzed a new collaboration between American researchers from the University of Delaware and Chinese researchers from the Sichuan Province Cultural Relics and Archeology Research Institute. They conducted joint fieldwork to survey the remaining traditional pottery workshops in Sichuan Province, as part of an investigation into the mechanisms of technological innovation and change. A large number of samples were collected from raw materials and finished products. These samples underwent laboratory analysis to help identify materials, technologies, and the properties of resulting products. The primary goal of documenting current technologies and interviewing potters and their customers about changes that have occurred was to identify circumstances that encourage and allow for the technological experimentation that is a necessary precursor to technological innovation and change. The researchers discovered that while a large number of traditional workshops have already disappeared and been replaced by modern industrial factories, Sichuan Province is still rich in surviving traditional pottery workshops. All of these surviving workshops have been officially recognized as part of China’s intangible cultural heritage, and some are clearly benefitting from newly-established Chinese policies in support of the preservation of traditional technological knowledge and skills.

 A rich variety of materials, fabrication and firing technologies, and products was found. This is consistent with Sichuan Province’s location at the crossroads of several major long-term trade routes, where potters and consumers had exposure to a variety of imported ceramic products over centuries. The presence of 17 ethnic groups and some unique local cultures also brings significant variety to ceramic traditions. The team studied traditional pottery technologies in the Aba Tibetan and Qiang Prefecture, Muli Tibetan Autonomous County, Derge County in the Garze Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Xichang (Liangshan Yi Autonomous Prefecture), and Mianyang, Pujiang, Rongxian, Yingjing, and Gaoxian Counties. Chronological depth was added by comparing these living workshops with products from archaeological kiln sites in Huili Ancient City (Liangshan Yi Autonomous Prefecture), Rongxian and Gaoxian Counties, and at Xiba ancient kiln in Leshan (central Sichuan).

Cultural support for experimentation was found to be a crucial factor that enhanced the ability of a workshop to change as needed to survive and thrive; with strong local leadership in heritage preservation ensuring that technological change could occur without destroying the most important aspects of cultural heritage that connect local people to their traditions. In one workshop, where both of these factors were lacking, project personnel interviewed the 86-year-old last remaining potter in the entire Prefecture. With no apprentices, and no ability to experiment and try new products to react to changing markets, this tradition is on the verge of disappearing. In contrast, in another Prefecture, active experimentation leading to change is coupled with strong local cultural heritage preservation efforts, and the pottery tradition is thriving and growing. The ancient material that is still used here (graphite-rich calcareous clay mixed with 50% talc) has properties in common with modern Corelle ware, so holds many advantages for cooking uses. Research at another group of workshops elsewhere in Sichuan Province revealed a unique material not known from anywhere else in the world, 50% powdered coal cinder mixed with 50% clay. A very innovative kiln and two-stage firing and ash-glazing process is also used, producing objects very well suited to the traditional cooking and dining practices of Sichuan Province.
